Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is caught stealing snacks at a store, and the parent needs to handle the situation
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A major news network has just called for an immediate on-air comment to counter misinformation in a breaking story.
Story: I was standing in the checkout line, my mind half on the groceries and half on the latest news alert about our cause, when I saw the store manager approach, holding my son gently by the arm. My heart dropped as I saw the half-eaten candy bar in his hand. The manager explained what happened, and I felt the weight of my responsibility as a parent—this was the moment to teach him about honesty, consequences, and making things right. But as I knelt to speak to him, my phone buzzed insistently. It was the major news network, calling for an immediate live comment to counter a wave of misinformation that could set our movement back months. I could hear the urgency in the producer’s voice, the expectation that I would step up and speak for everyone who counted on me. My son’s eyes were wide with fear and shame, and I could feel the eyes of the store staff on us, waiting for my response. My mind raced, torn between the lesson my child needed and the responsibility to my cause, both demanding my full attention at the very same moment.
